title: A cautionary tale: Unjust suspension by the automated disciplinary system
body:
Hi everyone. Yesterday I was taking a break from ranked and playing an ARAM when I used a phrase that was detected by the automated penalty system, and have been suspended for 14 days. As you all know, in ARAM games you cannot regenerate health at the fountain, and the only way to return to max health is to be healed by a teammate, by yourself, or to die and regenerate completely. On two occasions in the game, our Annie was at <20% HP, and members of the opposing team had just killed themselves to be full HP. Seeing this, I requested our team's Annie to kill herself too, but i made the mistake of using the no-no phrase "kys." Here is the chat log: 

My additions/context are in parentheses.

Game 1
lizardry: gj gunner        
~~(one of the teammates' names was gunner)
lizardry: waht kind of gunner are you
lizardry: oh shit
lizardry: nice
lizardry: you too vi
lizardry: annie kys
lizardry: i mean so u regen HP
lizardry: thats why they just suicided     
~~(at this point, Annie suicided, but she waited too long, once the enemy team was fully up again)
~~(several minutes later, Annie was again low HP, but this time suicided with good timing, so i congratulated her)
lizardry: KYS!!    
lizardry: yay
lizardry: that was beter        
lizardry: now wait for full 5
lizardry: that means you vi
lizardry: dont let htem backdoor us!
lizardry: i know its okay pal
lizardry: your heart was in the right place

As you can see, my phrasing was never directed to a player/person, but to the player's character in the context of a strategic situation. The tone of our team chat was never negative, and Annie responded positively during this interaction. In fact, I was the most honored person on our team, receiving honors from 3 teammates.  I have never been toxic to teammates before, have never received disciplinary action. I was D4/P1 the past two seasons, and level 5 honor. 

I understand why, if a different context, using the phrase "kys" or otherwise encouraging self-harm and lethality should deserve swift, harsh punishment. However, given the overall positive, non-toxic tone of our team chat, and the strategic situation, I am very surprised I was suspended for this. I submitted an appeal yesterday, and have not yet received a response from riot. Anyway, after reading through this forum for the first time, and having never been aware that an automated punitive system even exists, I wanted to submit my story for awareness so that others can avoid this situation in the future!

Happy huntin'

- Lizardry

replies.body:
I'm going to unban this as a false positive, since you have no other negative history.

But ... don't tell people to kys.

People might be used to feeling powerful behind a computer monitor where people don't know who they are, but that's not how we look at things.

if you were playing a game of basketball, and told someone to go kill themselves because you were frustrated about losing, you'd be penalized. Would you be punched in the face for telling someone at the bar to go kill themselves? Probably.

It's not 'PC'. It doesn't take 'testicles' to hide behind a monitor and tell someone to kill themselves or call them a racial slur. In fact, I'd say it's quite the opposite.
Not my word, that's why it's in quotes.
I think you missed my point of highlighting that word.

I suspect since the original post was deleted, many people may not realize your use of quotes as actually quoting the player in question.

That said, someone did quote the original post before it was deleted a little below, which adds some much needed context in your word choices.
It's pretty obvious to me. I mean, people need to use their brains, it's unlikely that a Rioter would just casually throw a word like that, and the quotations just make it obvious.

Along this line: 

What if someone was playing basketball and got dunked on which made them very upset. What if they muttered k*ll yourself under their breath and only their teammates and the referee heard them? Do you think that person would still be punished? Would their own team-mates punch them in the face? Or would they understand the player's frustration and reprimand him?
this "what would people we don't know do if x happened" scenario has no place here
Relax, I was posing a question based on tantrum's what if scenario. Why is mine any less valid than his?

because we have no ideea of knowing how other people may react to a given situation

Tantram's example implied that the verbal abuse was made out so everyone can hear and most sports rules clearly state what happens at such a time

your example was "what would happen if just the flamer's team heard him?" and it's quite a bit different. 

for instance i've seen quite a few times cases where someone was banned for being a bit too verbal in ally chat while in a premade and he was unbanned IF he was surrounded ONLY by premades who understood the banter and could vouch for him. if there was a non premade member in the team, the ban stayed. 

it depends on context of that nature. and since we don't know how the team who heard him thinks or tends to act we can't make an adequate assumption on what would happen

i'm sure you've seen cases where premades would report a toxic premade "as a joke" and it would go through and get them banned

Yes, my example is different, and that's why I'm asking it. No offense, but I wanted an answer from the rioter, not you. I want to know riot's position on the example I gave, so please don't disregard my question based on the pretense that it is a scenario that doesn't apply to this specific discussion. It may not be the same hypothetical scenario, but it is a similar one, and I would very much appreciate an answer by a rioter.

> but I wanted an answer from the rioter, not you.

good luck waiting, you won't receive answers on that kind of questions.

> [{quoted}](name=CooL Ice Tea,realm=EUW,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=3zQ7hXi0,comment-id=000400050000000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2017-11-17T07:02:44.054+0000)
>

I'll just keep asking questions until I get one. One of my dad's favorite sayings was "the squeaky wheel gets the oil", and that's how I approach most things that I truly care about.
As long as you are polite and not aggressive, I agree with your strategy (and your dad's saying) ^^
What would be the League-equivalent of this scenario?
It would be saying k_s or f_ck you in chat out of frustration when an enemy player kills you, but not hitting the all-chat button. The player wouldn't see the message, but your team would.

Then my answer is simple: why do you need to write those insults out? Of course I get angry at playing too, but in that case I just cuss out lout, and that's it. Why should I even make the effort to open chat and write insults? It's slower, and has no additional benefit (but rather it's risky because I can be reported). I only wirte something in chat when I can be supportive and cheering, if I want to release stress or anger, I say it to myself (or maybe in Teamspeak/discord with my friends).

And another thing: I personally hate when people start flaming in chat, even if it's not against me, even if the other person doesn't read the flame: it's distracting, and brings kills the mood. It distracts _me_, and it bothers _me_.

Of course I don't need to type these things, it's what we call a lapse in judgement. Honestly, I type very fast when I need to and typing is literally the only form of communication in this video game, so is it really that unlikely that I would type something I should have said out loud and say something I should be typing?
I, also don not like being flamed, but I generally consider flame to be more than 2 lines of dialogue. (just my opinion though)

I'm not a native english speaker and I beg you to use a bit of charitable reading with me: when I write "flame" I just mean aggressive/whiny comments, anything that's written out of anger, stress or frustration. Such comments, even if it's just an "omg" make people more tense and more prone to heating up, which is very bad for winning :)

With your "lapse in judgement" you're still making the game wors for four other players, even when they're not the target of your grief. This doesn't mean that anything one writes to relieve stress should be punished, but it's also not what happens with the IFS, so that's not a topic. 
If I'm able to not write my frustration in chat, you can too, and I expect you not to.

Also, I find the ping system to be a very valid system for communication. There are still things you can't ping, but most of the important things for gameplay you can communicate without typing, imo
If a ref heard then they would likely be penalized for unsportsmanlike conduct.

I've played a lot of basketball and currently referee as part of my second job, and I can honestly tell you that the most something like this would merit is a warning if anything at all. Those are just my experiences in playing basketball for the past 15 years, though.
I was referring to professional play.....

Sit courtside at an NBA game sometime, I assure you that the only time words are ever penalized is if they are directed at an official for a prolonged period of time.  You would be amazed what players say to each other on the court at an NBA game---or maybe you wouldn't, but either way it is not for children and definitely consists of racial slurs, profanity and a ton of trash talk.

> if you were playing a game of basketball, and told someone to go kill themselves because you were frustrated about losing, you'd be penalized. Would you be punched in the face for telling someone at the bar to go kill themselves? Probably.

If someone punches another human being in the face that is called 'assault' and it is against the law, telling someone to go 'kill themselves' is not against the law and is therefore not punishable, there would be no 'penalties'.  If you're talking about a penalty in pro basketball, well then I would suggest you sit courtside at an NBA game... "kill yourself" would be about the least offensive thing you'll hear on the court that night.  I've been to many NBA games through the years and had season tickets 4 rows up and heard plenty of things that would get you an instant ban in League, but not even so much as a turn of the head from the officials on the floor.  

> It's not 'PC'. It doesn't take 'testicles' to hide behind a monitor and tell someone to kill themselves or call them a racial slur. In fact, I'd say it's quite the opposite.

I'll agree with this part.  

Honestly, I think it's a tad silly to punish someone for saying "kill yourself [kys]" in an online video game.  People do need thicker skins... I could understand it if the person made a legitimate death threat or told them that they knew where they lived and would inflict bodily harm on them... but, while I believe saying "kys" makes you an asshole it shouldn't be an instant ban, that's just nonsense.

And people wonder why suicide rates rise. Instead of telling kids that words can't hurt you, we tell them that words hurt and should be taken very seriously and we should censor the world to protect them, because they are so dangerous. How does that help a kid struggling with bullying?!

...It helps because having people stand alongside you makes things feel less hopeless. Having someone say "that's not how you should treat others" when you're bullied might make you believe you don't deserve it.

"If your feelings are hurt, maybe you should stop having them" is a terrible message to spread. When somebody punches you, you choose to punch them back or not. You don't get to choose for it not to hurt. You only choose your reaction. Why would it be any different for emotions?

Oh, and as for your comment about suicide rates: maybe it's because technology has changed, not people. Maybe that message of thick skin has always been wrong and previous mitigating factors have been removed. Maybe people have always been weak enough to let words affect them, but the unifying power of technology has allowed those words to surround people with more force than ever before.

You are speaking of the zero tolerance system, and not the machine learning system. That was mostly BS, but even then it's not abusing the system. That is pre game hostage taking which is something completely different and unrelated to the machine learning systems.

 You're making a case for why there needs to be more systems to cover edge case of trolling.

Dammit again Tantram, how much more stuff do you need to suprise us every day  and we need to update our own knowledge base :(

Straight up, how many different systems are there within the whole behavioral system?

You know about all of them.

The IFS (Instant Feedback System) system calls out to multiple services for evaluation. I should probably write a tech blog on this. There are different services that evaluate verbal harassment, zero tolerance, intentional feeding, afk'ing, etc.

Let's say that tomorrow we needed a new service to evaluate ... morse code. We would write a new service module and register it with the IFS. We simplify the discussion and just usually say IFS. But the reality is there is a very complex group of systems that support player behavior.
